body.p:
Elkton January 12th 1864.
His Excellency Thomas E Bramlette.
Dear Sir.
I was called on this morning, by Mr. Henry Mitchell, to recommend him, to executive clemency.

I can & do cheerfully state for him, that I have known him long, & have ever regarded him, as a sober discreet, well behaved man, he is poor, indeed insolvent, & I suppose his securities, will be compelled to pay the fine, should the same be collected.

I can further state that I was present, at the trial, was not engaged in the case & from my casual hearing of the evidence & speeches made by lawyers, the impression was made on my mind that he would be acquitted, & was somewhat surprised, at a different result.

This is all that I can say, am usually well satisfied with the action of our executive & of course will be in this case, but am inclined to believe, that at least a part of the fine, should be remitted.

I have the honor to be respectfully &c.
F. M. Bristow

Todd Cir Ct
vs
Henry Mitchell
$300 Oct term/ 63
violating Tavern Bond
Remitted
9th Feby 1864

Remit all except $100 fees & costs
Tho E Bramlette
